term.definition: Grouping of related academic units within a College.
term.notes:
This field is similar to the College field but has one primary difference - the College of Arts and Letters is divided into the Humanities and Social Sciences divisions.  Other colleges are mapped to a division bearing the same name as their college.

The Graduate School division is used to administratively group graduate and professional programs that do not belong to one of the other divisions.

The University division is used to administratively group students who are assigned to the University college (see College definition).  This would include activity associated with pre-college, Saint Mary’s, Semester On-Line and Holy Cross College.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present
term.name: Academic Division

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Indicates whether a student has achieved the minimum academic standards for his or her academic program in a given academic term.  Students who are not in academic good standing are on academic probation.
term.notes:
Determination of academic good standing for undergraduate degree-seeking students is made as follows:

  • First-semester students in the First Year of Studies must achieve a minimum term GPA of 1.700.
  • Second-semester students in the First Year of Studies must achieve a minimum term GPA of 1.850.
  • Students in the sophomore year and beyond must achieve a minimum term GPA of 2.000.

Determination of academic good standing for degree-seeking students in the Graduate School is made as follows:

  • Students must maintain a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher
  • Ph.D. students must pass their candidacy exam by the end of their eighth academic term in the program
  • Students must not receive two consecutive grades of Unsatisfactory in Research and Dissertation

Determination of academic good standing for Law students is made as follows:

  • First-year students must achieve a minimum term GPA of 1.500 for the first semester and 1.750 for the second semester.
  • Second- and third-year students must achieve a minimum term GPA of 2.000.

Non-degree seeking students in the Graduate School who are enrolled and making satisfactory progress are considered in good academic standing.  Academic standing is not determined for other non-degree seeking students.
term.data_availability:
Data is available from Fall 1982 to the present for undergraduate and Law students.

Although other colleges may determine academic good standing for graduate, professional and non-degree-seeking students, this information is not available in the data warehouse.
term.name: Academic Standing

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The average of the grade quality points for all students enrolled in a specific Class unweighted by credit hours
term.notes:
To calculate the Class Average Grade:

For all students registered for and receiving a grade that awards grade quality points for a given Class:
(sum of grade quality points) / (the number of students receiving grades that have grade quality points)

Grade quality points are defined as:

  • A = 4.000 quality points)
  • A- = 3.667 quality points
  • B+ = 3.333 quality points
  • B = 3.000 quality points
  • B- = 2.667 quality points
  • C+ = 2.333 quality points
  • C = 2.000 quality points
  • C- = 1.667 quality points
  • D = 1.000 quality points
  • X = 0.000 quality points
  • I = 0.000 quality points
  • F = 0.000 quality points

Students with grades that are not used in the calculation of a student’s GPA (e.g., S, U, V, W, P, F* and NR) are not used in calculating the Course Average Grade.

For example:

HIST30123-01 is a Class that has two cross-listed sections (HIST30123-01, the parent, and AMST20111-01, the child)  There are 4 students registered for HIST30123-01 and 3 students registered for AMST20111-01 (total of 7 students registered for the Class).  The 7 students receive the following grades, respectively: A, A, B, B, C, P, and F.  The Class Average Grade would be calculated as: (4+4+3+2+0)/6 or 2.66, corresponding to a B-.  

Note that the student’s “P” grade does not factor into the calculation as the “P” does not count toward calculating a GPA.
term.name: Class Average Grade

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The total number of students registered for a Class, regardless of the students’ for-credit or not for-credit status in the Class.
term.notes:
The Class Enrollment is equal to the Course Section Enrollment in the case of a Course Section that has no cross listings (solo) or the sum of the enrollments of the collection of cross-listed Course Sections (parent and child cross-listings).

The difference between Class Enrollment and Class For-Credit Enrollment will equal the number of students enrolled in Class for 0 credit.

term.definition: Represents the date an employee established a regular employment relationship with the University, taking into account breaks in service and periods of temporary/on call employment.
term.notes:
If an exempt or non-exempt employee leaves regular employment with the University and returns to regular employment with the University within 12 months or less, one year of service is lost and the Adjusted Service Date is updated to reflect the loss of one year of service.

If an exempt or non-exempt employee returns to regular employment with the University after 12 months, all previous service is lost. The Adjusted Service Date is the date the employee returned to the University.

See also “Employee Original Hire Date” and “Employee Current Hire Date”.

term.definition: The Career Stream identifies the general nature of work performed within a family.
term.notes:
Further definition of the Career Streams are as follows:

  • NIC – Refers to employees, who because of the type of duties performed, the usual level of decision making authority, and the method of compensation, are subject to all Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) provisions including the payment of overtime. Non - exempt employees are normally required to account for all hours worked.
  • EIC - Refers to employees who, because of their positional duties and responsibilities and level of decision making authority, are exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)
  • M – Refers to employees who are responsible for supervising 3 or more regular staff members

Some jobs, such as “Faculty”, “Post Doc”, “Coach”, “Officer” and “Intern”, are not represented by Career Stream and Level designations

See also “Career Level”.
term.name: Career Stream

term.definition: Job families are categories of positions that involve work in the same functional occupation and have related core knowledge and background requirements.
term.possible_values:
• Academic Affairs
  • Athletics
  • Auxiliary Services
  • Engineering
  • Environment & Safety
  • External/Internal Relations
  • Facilities
  • Financial Management
  • General Administration
  • Health Services
  • Hotel
  • Human Resources
  • Information Technology
  • Library
  • Student Services
term.notes:
Jobs in a job family are similar in that they:

  • Require similar knowledge, skills and abilities (competencies).
  • Have a continuum of knowledge, skills and abilities that represent a career path from the lowest to the highest level job.
  • Possess associated and related key behaviors.
  • Have similar market competitive pay characteristics and conditions.

Some jobs, such as “Faculty”, “Post Doc”, “Coach”, “Officer” and “Intern”, are not represented by Career Stream and Level designations.

See also “Job Sub-Family”.
term.name: Job Family

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Job Sub-Families are groupings of jobs that fit a specific occupational area within a family that are similar in educational background, experience/competencies required and market value
term.possible_values:
Examples of Job Sub-Families are:

  • Compliance (within the Athletics Job Family)
  • Facility Management (within the Engineering Job Family)
  • Public Affairs (within the External/Internal Relations Job Family)
term.notes:
There is a unique set of Job Sub-Families for each Job Family.

Some jobs, such as “Faculty”, “Post Doc”, “Coach”, “Officer” and “Intern”, are not represented by Career Stream and Career Level designations

See also “Job Family”.
term.name: Job Sub-Family

The Job Suffix is grouped with the ndID and Position Number to uniquely associate an individual with a position and a job within the position.

term.definition: Describes the purpose for granting a particular Faculty Appointment.

• Faculty New Hire - An appointment granted to an individual who did not hold an appointment during the immediate prior Academic Term in the same Faculty Category.
  • Promotion - An appointment granted to an individual due to either:
    • An upward change in Faculty Rank within the same Faculty Category
    • Change in Tenure Status to “Tenured”
    • Change in Endowed Status to “Endowed”
  • Reappointment - An appointment granted to an individual who held an appointment at the same rank during the immediate prior Academic Term.
  • Emeritus - An appointment granted to an individual upon receiving Emeritus Faculty status.
term.notes: Individuals who are promoted at the time they receive an Emeritus appointment are given a Faculty Appointment Reason of Emeritus and are not included in a promotion-related Faculty Cohort.

term.definition: A group of faculty members who share a common characteristic during a particular Academic Year.
term.possible_values:
Faculty Cohorts are described by two attributes:

  • Faculty Cohort Year
  • Faculty Cohort Type

They are named according to the combination of those terms.  For example, the cohort containing all faculty members who were promoted to Associate Professor in AY14 is named “Faculty Cohort AY14 Associate Professor”
term.notes:
Currently, Notre Dame includes faculty members in new Faculty Cohorts when they receive a new Faculty Appointment (New Faculty Hire) during a given Academic Year.  In all cases, the faculty member is added to the Faculty Cohort corresponding to the Faculty Appointment Reason associated with their new Faculty Appointment (New Faculty Hire) for that Academic Year.

In cases where the Faculty Appointment Reason is New Appointment (New Faculty Hire), the faculty member is also added to the Faculty Cohort corresponding to the Faculty Category associated with their new Faculty Appointment for that Academic Year.

In cases where the Faculty Appointment Reason is New Appointment or Promotion, the faculty member is also added to the Faculty Cohort corresponding to the Faculty Rank associated with their new Faculty Appointment for that Academic Year.

For example:

  • A faculty member hired as a new Assistant Professor in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Assistant”, the “Faculty Cohort AY14 New Faculty Hire”, and the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Tenured & Tenure Track” cohorts.
  • A faculty member promoted from Assistant Professor to Associate Professor with Tenure in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Associate”, “Faculty Cohort AY14 Granted Tenure” and the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Promotion”
  • A faculty member who is reappointed as an Associate Professor during AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Reappointment”
  • A faculty member who joins the Emeritus Faculty in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Emeritus”
  • A faculty member who was an Assistant Professor in AY06 and rejoins the University as an Associate Professor in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Associate”, the “Faculty Cohort AY14 New Faculty Hire”, and the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Tenured & Tenure Track” cohorts.
  • A faculty member who was an Associate Professor in AY06 and rejoins the University as an Associate Professor in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Associate”, the “Faculty Cohort AY14 New Faculty Hire”, and the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Tenured & Tenure Track” cohorts.
  • A faculty member who moves from an SPF position to become an Assistant Professor in AY14 is added to the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Assistant”, the “Faculty Cohort AY14 New Faculty Hire”, and the “Faculty Cohort AY14 Tenured & Tenure Track” cohorts.

Faculty Cohort membership is permanent.  A faculty member remains part of every cohort they join during their career.  For example, a faculty member who is newly hired as an Assistant Professor in AY14, is reappointed at that rank in AY17, is promoted to Associate Professor with Tenure in AY20, is reappointed at that rank in AY23 and AY26 and is promoted to Professor in AY29 would be in the following cohorts:

  • Faculty Cohort AY14 New Faculty Hire
  • Faculty Cohort AY14 Assistant
  • Faculty Cohort AY14 Tenured & Tenure Track
  • Faculty Cohort AY17 Reappointment
  • Faculty Cohort AY20 Associate
  • Faculty Cohort AY20 Promotion
  • Faculty Cohort AY20 Granted Tenure
  • Faculty Cohort AY23 Reappointment
  • Faculty Cohort AY26 Reappointment
  • Faculty Cohort AY29 Full
  • Faculty Cohort AY29 Promotion

term.definition: Describes a single regular faculty appointment between the University and an individual where two academic units simultaneously approve/grant that individual an appointment as defined in Article III of the Academic Articles.
term.notes:
See also “Faculty Appointment”.

The Joint Appointment is a unique situation that grants an individual regular faculty status in two academic units as a single appointment.

The joint appointment must be formally recognized in the faculty appointment letter.

The first academic unit listed in the appointment letter will be defined as the Primary Appointment and the second academic unit listed will be defined as the Faculty Joint Appointment.

The faculty rank, category and tenure status must be the same for both simultaneous appointments.

As such, when counting Active Faculty at the University, the individual holding a joint appointment will be counted once.  When counting Appointments, the individual will be counted once.  However, when counting appointments by granting academic unit, the individual will be counted once in each granting academic unit.

Rules governing how appointments are granted are found in Article III, section 4 of the Academic Articles.

Faculty Appointments may be defined for a particular period of time or may have indefinite duration.

term.definition: Accounting string used to record a financial transaction.  FOAPAL is an acronym standing for Fund-Organization-Account-Program-Activity-Location.
term.possible_values:
Hyphenated string consisting of a combination of:

  • Fund Number
  • Organization Number
  • Account Number
  • Program Number
  • Activity Number (optional - see definition)
  • Location Number (optional - see defintion)

For example:

  • 100000-29000-72454-70000
  • 371752-29090-65000-70000
  • 309200-43325-72001-20001-38362-1080
  • 201387-35045-66132-20000-11117-1050
  • 370428-34015-72299-40000-15304-1148
term.notes: The FOAPAL string associated with Banner transactions provides intelligence about the transaction.  The intelligence encoded in the FOAPAL string allows us to understand such details as the source of funding, the department or unit that is spending or receiving funding, the nature of the activity (what was received or purchased) and the reason for the activity in varying levels of detail.
term.name: FOAPAL

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Literal descriptor that identifies the type of transaction activity
term.possible_values:
Any string up to 35 characters in length.  For example:

Account Number        Account Description
64010                         Staff-Administrative
71297                         Telecommunications-Toll
72591                         Rental Equipment
13100                         Retail
term.notes:
The Account information contained in this field represents the data entry level from the Account hierarchy.

The Banner Finance User Guide defines the account code as representing “a line item within a site's financial structure. Categories include general ledger accounts (assets and liabilities) and operating ledger accounts (revenues and expenses).”  This is consistent with the use of the account code within Notre Dame’s chart of accounts.  The account code hierarchy is broadly divided into general ledger accounts (assets, liabilities, control accounts and fund balance accounts) and operating ledger accounts (revenues, expenditures and transfers), with layers of hierarchy within each major type of account.

In the context of a given transaction’s FOAPAL string, the account code identifies “what” is being accrued, depreciated, earned, purchased, received or transferred.

Examples in which account codes would be assigned to represent an activity include a specific type of gift, the purchase of office supplies, payment of salaries, depreciation of an asset, accrual of interest payable, or the movement of fund balance between funds.
term.name: FOAPAL Account Description

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The portion of a FOAPAL used to identify projects, special events and recurring campus activities
term.possible_values:
Five digit value.  For example:

FOAPAL Activity Code         FOAPAL Activity Description
10100                                   Commencement
10125                                   Faculty Recruiting
41978                                   Fr. Ted Fun Run/Walk
10220                                   Retreats
60137                                   Pep Rallies
term.notes:
The Activity information contained in this field represents the data entry level from the Activity hierarchy.

Use of the FOAPAL Activity Code/FOAPAL Activity Description fields on a transaction is optional, unless required by a business rule.

The Banner Finance User Guide defines the activity code as “an accounting element for use in tracking non-budget-control financial affairs.”  Notre Dame’s use of the activity code is indeed for tracking activity that is not budgeted at the central level, but may represent activity budgeted outside of Banner at a level of detail relevant to a given unit’s operations (e.g. Kellogg Institute).   

A fair degree of discretion is allowed at the unit level as to how the activity code element is employed.  Generally, though, this element would be used to identify an organization’s programmatic activities at a more detailed level than what is embodied in the program code.  Activity codes may represent specific individual events or other components of an organization’s programs.  For example, if one of an organization’s programs is “professional development”, activity codes identifying events such as the “Higher Education Accounting Forum, May 2012” might be used to provide further detail about how resources were expended for professional development.
term.name: FOAPAL Activity Code

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The portion of a FOAPAL corresponding to the source from which funds are drawn.
term.possible_values:
Six digit value that is normally assigned according to the following schedule:

FOAPAL Fund Type FOAPAL Fund Code (6 digits)
Current Unrestricted 1xxxxx
Grants/Contracts 2xxxxx
Designated/Discretionary 3xxxxx
Student Loan Fund 4xxxxx
Endowment 6xxxxx
Split Interest Agreements 7xxxxx
Agency Accounts 8xxxxx
Plant Fund 9xxxxx

For example:

FOAPAL Fund Code FOAPAL Fund Description
120000 Athletic Administration
250051 Elkhart Environmental Center
370013 Eck Visitor Center
400710 Stafford Loans-Federal
632940 Remick Center-Ethics & Culture
800270 Tax Assistance Program
900152 London Facility
term.notes:
The fund information contained in this field represents the data entry level from the fund hierarchy.

In Notre Dame’s chart of accounts, the fund code represents a distinct resource pool controlled either centrally or by an organization within the University, for which separate accounting is required for budgetary or stewardship purposes.  The fund code hierarchy at the highest level is organized by the type of resource that is represented (i.e. current funds, endowment, split-interest funds, etc.).  Within each type of fund, the lower levels of hierarchy are organized differently, but across all fund types the fund code still embodies a single resource pool.  

In the context of a given transaction’s FOAPAL string, the fund code embodies the resource pool that is either the funding source of expenditures or transfers out, or recipient of revenue or transfers in.  Expenditures or funding transfers out reduce the fund’s available balance (actual or budget), while revenues and funding transfers in increase the fund’s balance.

Examples of situations in which a new fund code may be warranted include the receipt of a gift restricted to a specific purpose, a grant for sponsored research, the opening of a new capital project, or the designation of unrestricted resources to support a specific initiative such as a faculty chair.
term.name: FOAPAL Fund Code

The Organization information contained in this field represents the data entry level from the Organization hierarchy.

The Banner Finance User Guide defines the organization code as representing “a department within the installation.”  This is consistent with the use of the organization code within Notre Dame’s chart of accounts.  The organization code hierarchy generally reflects Notre Dame’s organizational structure for management purposes.  Individual organization codes at the data entry level represent units with operational accountability for funds.

In the context of a given transaction’s FOAPAL string, the organization code identifies “who” is spending, transferring or receiving resources.

New organization codes would generally only be warranted upon the creation of new academic, administrative or auxiliary departments (i.e. the code represents a group that exists for some purpose, but not the purpose itself).  However, there may be circumstances in which an organization code would be established to identify a given department’s share of the activity of a cross-disciplinary initiative.  For example, a Strategic Research Initiative (SRI) may be identified at the organization level 7, with individual data entry-level organization codes representing the academic departments (e.g. biology, chemical engineering, etc.) that are to be credited for a portion of the SRI’s activities.  To be clear, this has not to date been incorporated in the chart of accounts, but is mentioned just to recognize that the optimal model for accounting for such “hybrid” entities as the SRIs remains unsettled.

Organization codes should not duplicate activity that would be represented in another element of the FOAPAL string, such as the account or program code.  For example, departmental salaries represent an operational cost to an organization, but do not represent an organization itself.  Salaries represent “what” is being consumed or acquired, but not “who” is consuming or acquiring and would be accounted for with the account code.  From a slightly different perspective, categories of an organization’s activities, such as “operations” or “administration,” are indicative of “why” an organization expends or acquires resources, but are not organizations themselves.  Such categories of activities may be most appropriately represented by the program or activity code elements.
term.name: FOAPAL Organization Code

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The portion of a FOAPAL that identifies the purpose of related financial transactions.  The program number describes the University’s major activities.
term.possible_values:
Program Codes are generally assigned according to the following schedule:

FOAPAL Program Code FOAPAL Program Description
10000 Instruction
10001 Departmental Research
10002 Online Instruction
20000 Organized Sponsored Research
20001 Organized Internal Research
30000 Public Service
40000 Academic Support
50000 Student Activities
60000 O&M-Services & Service
60001 O&M-Academic & Admin BldgsO&
60002 O&M Direct
70000 General Administration
70001 Fundraising
91000 Auxilliary Enterprises
92000 Student Financial Aid
99000 University
term.notes:
The Program information contained in this field represents the data entry level from the Program hierarchy.

The Banner Finance User Guide defines the program code as “a defined function. Programs enable you to establish a method of pulling transactions across organizations and accounts. Examples include instruction, research, and plant operations. Most educational institutions (including the University of Notre Dame) use programs defined by the National Association of College and University Business Officers (NACUBO). This also is consistent with the use of the program code as currently employed by Notre Dame, and as envisioned to accommodate ARP.  It is also important to note that the program code may also be used to aggregate transactions across funds, as well as organizations and accounts.  

In the context of a given transaction’s FOAPAL string, the program code identifies “why” resources are expended (or possibly received or transferred).  The “why” embodied in the program code may be broadly defined as it is now (e.g. instruction, research, etc.) or more narrowly focused (e.g. undergraduate instruction, graduate instruction, etc.) depending on the expressed needs of ARP constituents.  

Generally, program codes should not duplicate intelligence embodied in another FOAPAL element, such as the organization or account code.  For example, “faculty salaries” are an operational cost of an organization, but represent a “what”—compensation for academic service—that is best captured in the account code.  The activity performed by the respective faculty, or the “why” they are compensated (e.g. for teaching, performing research, etc.), is the relevant activity that should be represented in the program code.

Prior to July 1, 2013, Program Numbers used by the University were two digits.
term.name: FOAPAL Program Code

term.definition: A calendar date.
term.notes: Full date is specified in the format mm/dd/yyyy, where mm stands for the 2-digit month code, dd stands for the 2-digit day of the month and yyyy stands for the 4-digit calendar year.
term.name: Full Date

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Contains the expected cash earnings to be paid annually to an individual for a particular job.
term.notes: For hourly employees, Job Salary is calculated as the product of their hourly rate and their expected number of hours worked.
term.name: Job Salary

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Contains the actual change in Job Salary between two points in time, expressed as a dollar amount.
term.notes: To determine the job salary change, the same job can only be compared to itself between two points in time.
term.name: Job Salary Change

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Contains the actual change in Job Salary between two points in time, expressed as a percentage.
term.notes: To determine the job salary change, the same job can only be compared to itself between two points in time.
term.name: Job Salary Change Percent

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Contains the combinations of FOAPAL(s) and percentages that describe the funding sources for a particular Job.
term.possible_values:
Any set of valid FOAPALs where the percentages sum to 100%.  For example:

FOAPAL
Percentage
100000-29010-63030-70000 50%
309200-43325-63030-20001-38362-1080 50%
term.notes:
Each FOAPAL contained within the Job Salary Labor Distribution for a particular Job may also be referred to as a Job Salary Funding Source.

The percentage that each Job Salary Funding Source contributes to a particular Job’s funding may also be referred to as a Job Salary Funding Percentage.

In cases where the FOAPAL(s) charged for a Job were adjusted after a payroll date, those changes will not be reflected in the Job Salary Labor Distribution data.  This information shows the FOAPAL(s) that were charged at the time of a particular payroll date.
term.name: Job Salary Labor Distribution

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Indicates whether a job is the primary, secondary or overload job for an individual.
term.possible_values:
• Primary - the job held by an individual that is their primary reason for being at the university at any given point in time
  • Secondary - additional jobs that contribute toward 403(b) benefits for exempt employees
  • Overload - additional jobs that do not contribute toward 403(b) benefits
term.notes:
Non-student employees may not have a secondary job unless their primary job is eligible for retirement benefits.

Student employees are never eligible for retirement benefits but all jobs other than their primary job are recorded as secondary jobs.

For non-retirees, the primary job is always the same as the Core Job.  For retirees, the primary job is tied to a retiree position.
term.name: Job Type

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The academic unit that shares a joint faculty appointment with the Appointment Approving Academic Unit.
term.notes:
Joint Appointment Approving Academic Unit is tied with an Appointment Approving Academic Unit to an individual appointment. Therefore, a faculty member with a Joint Appointment will have both an Appointment Approving Academic Unit and a Joint Appointment Approving Academic Unit.

The first academic unit listed in the appointment letter will be defined as the Appointment Approving Academic Unit and the second academic unit listed will be defined as the Joint Appointment Approving Academic Unit.
term.name: Joint Appointment Approving Academic Unit

term.name: Last Refreshed

Month Number Month End Day Number

  • Valued
  • Requires Improvement
  • Developing

(where the first is the “Values” rating and the second is the “Goals/Expectations” rating)

OR

For example:

  • Not Complete

A Job is the association of a Position with an Employee.

term.possible_values:
The Position Number is in the form ANNNNN where:

A is “S” for Staff, “F” for Faculty, “T” for Temp, U for Undergraduate, G for Graduate, P for Postdoc…

NNNNN is a five digit number.
term.notes:
Responsibility for this term is shared as follows:

  • Human Resources (Positions that start with “S”, “T”, and “U”)
  • Graduate School (Positions that start with “P” and “G”)
  • Provost (Positions that start with “F”)

See also “Position” and “Job”
term.name: Position Number

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The Job Number is the combination of a Position Number and the Job Suffix.
term.notes:
See also “Job” and “Job Suffix”.

The Job Number is formed at the time a position is filled by an employee.

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.possible_values:
Examples of Position Titles are:

  • M1 Supervisor
  • EIC3 Specialist
  • NIC2 Coordinator
  • Post Doctoral Research Associate
term.notes:
For staff, it is generally based on the Career Stream and Career Level.  For other jobs it may be a textual description

This term should not be used to report on Faculty and is intended for Staff reporting.

See also “Job”, “Working Title”, “Position” and “Position Number”.
term.name: Position Title

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.possible_values:
Examples of Working Titles are:

  • Manager, Human Resources Information Services
  • Sustainability, Associate Program Manager
term.notes:
See also “Job” and “Job Number”.

Working Titles are typically finalized once a Position is filled by an Employee and becomes a “Job”.

Working Titles are utilized in the university directory and for daily business purposes, selected from a list of title options based upon career stream and level and approved by Human Resources.

Working Titles typically only apply to Staff Jobs.

http://hr.nd.edu/assets/24321/titling_guidelines.pdf

  • AAA - American Indian or Alaska Native
  • CCC - White
  • TWO - Two or more races selected

term.definition: Describes a Job change event where an individual who does not currently hold any existing Staff Job with the university is assigned to a Staff Job with the university.

When measuring or counting, the event occurs at the time the Job starts.

Individuals who have faculty appointments or temp jobs, when assigned to a Staff Job meeting the definition criteria, count as a “Staff New Hire” event.

See also “Staff Promotion”, “Staff Separation”, “Staff Transfer”
term.name: Staff New Hire

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
Describes a Job change event where any of the following apply:

  • A person moves to a higher career level position within the same career stream;
  • A person moves from a non-exempt individual contributor position to an exempt individual contributor or a manager position;
  • An exempt individual contributor position moves to a manager position
term.notes:
Promotion events include guidelines and policies around compensation changes.

Consult HR Compensation for further specifics around Promotion events.

Data captured between 7/1/2010 and 7/1/2012 may have reliability issues due to inconsistent classification of events as “promotions”.  

Data prior to 7/1/2010 will not conform to this definition.

See also “Staff Transfer”, “Staff Separation”, “Staff New Hire”
term.data_availability: Beginning 7/1/2010
term.name: Staff Promotion

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Describes a Staff Job change event where an individual moves from one distinct Staff position to another Staff position without an interim separation and does not meet the criteria of a promotion.
term.notes:
Consult HR Compensation for further specifics around Promotion events.

Data captured between 7/1/2010 and 7/1/2012 may have reliability issues due to inconsistent classification of events as “promotions”.  

Data prior to 7/1/2010 will not conform to this definition.

“Demotions” are a specific type of “transfer” and are not addressed in the governance and business intelligence models.

See also “Staff Promotion”, “Staff Separation”, “Staff New Hire”
term.data_availability: Data is available for transfers after 7/1/2010.

• NetIDs consist of between 3-8 alphanumeric characters.

  • Normally, the first character of a NetID is the first letter of an individual’s first name.  The remaining characters are a person’s last name. 

  •  In the cases of individuals with last names greater than seven characters, the name is truncated after the seventh character.

  •  If the NetID generated by the process above is already in use, a digit is appended to the NetID to make it unique.  If this would result in the NetID becoming longer than eight characters, characters are truncated from the individual’s last name to make the NetID eight characters.
term.notes:
• As of 2002, NetIDs are not reused and an individual retains his or her NetID for life.  Prior to that date, NetIDs were reused if available at the time of assignment.

  • Normally, NetIDs are assigned automatically during the account creation process using the format described above.  NetIDs are only changed at an individual’s request in three circumstances:

  1. a legal name change due to divorce or annulment

  2. misspelling of a legal name

  3. a combination of letters and/or numbers that results in an obscene or derogatory word, or that reflects negatively on the University.

  • Prior to 2002, NetIds were referred to as AFS IDs.

  • The NetID Standard is described here: http://oit.nd.edu/policies-standards/information-technology-standards/netid-standard/
term.data_availability: NetIDs are available for all individuals associated with the University in 1991 or later.
term.name: Individual NetID

term.definition: Contains the last name of an individual.
term.notes:
This field is concatenated into the “Name, Full” field, which contains an individual’s full name, consisting of first name, middle name, last name and suffix.

This field is also known as family name and surname.

Data entry into source systems must conform to the rules below, taken from the Data Integrity Standards.

All information is to be entered using title-case format (uppercase/lowercase letters).  Do not use all uppercase letters.  Enter the legal spelling and format of the last name, using standard capitalization rules.

If a last name legally begins with a lowercase first character, the name should be entered with the lowercase (e.g., dellaToria).  You need to remember that when searching or sorting names, they will appear after all capital letters (e.g., dellaToria would be after Zwick).

  • Hyphens may be used to separate double last names.  They are sometimes used by persons who wish to utilize their maiden and married names, but should be entered without a space immediately before and after the hyphen (Jones-Smith).  However, if there are two last names unhyphenated (e.g., Martha Lee Creton Quinton), Martha would be input as the first name; Lee would be input as the middle name; and Creton Quinton would be input as the last name.

  • Spaces should be used to separate multiple last names unless the last name is hyphenated.

  • Periods should rarely be entered in last name field (see examples below).

  • No Commas should be entered in last name field.  The suffix should be entered in the suffix field.

  • Apostrophes may be used in such names as O’Leary, O’Connor, etc., but they should be entered without a space immediately before or after the apostrophe.

  • Do not use titles, prefixes or suffixes in the first or last name fields.  Use the prefix and suffix fields for this data. (e.g., Dr., Mr., Mrs., III, Jr., etc., should never be entered in the first or last name field.)

  • For F-1 and J-1 international student and J-1 employees, it is important that the name be entered exactly as it appears on the passport.
term.name: Name, Last

term.definition: Contains the first name of an individual.
term.possible_values: Alphabetic string
term.notes:
This field is concatenated into the “Name, Full” field, which contains an individual’s full name, consisting of first name, middle name, last name and suffix. This field is also known as given name and forename.

Data entry into source systems must conform to the rules below, taken from the Data Integrity Standards.

All information is to be entered using title-case format (uppercase/lowercase letters).  Never use all uppercase letters.  Enter the legal first name, using standard capitalization rules.

  • Hyphens may be used to separate double names, but do not use spaces before or after the hyphen.

  • Apostrophes may be used, but do not use spaces before or after the apostrophe.

  • Spaces are permitted between multiple names (e.g., Mary Ann).

  • Enter the full first name in this field.

  • As a general rule, single character first names should be entered with a period in the first name field.  However, if their legal names do not have a period, do not enter a period.

  • The middle name or middle initial should be entered in the middle name field.  If only a middle initial is known, follow the initial with a period.

  • Do not enter titles, prefixes or suffixes in the first or last name fields.  Use the prefix or suffix fields for this data.
term.name: Name, First

term.definition: Contains the information necessary to uniquely identify and contact, by telephone, a particular subscriber.
term.notes:
The telephone number may contain a U.S./Canada number, an international access code and phone number or both.

U.S. and Canada domestic phone numbers begin with a 3-digit area code followed by a 3-digit exchange, a 4-digit local number and, if used an extension number.

International phone numbers being with a 2- to 4-digit International call prefix, a country code, and the telephone number (which may include a city/area code and local number).

term.definition: Contains information about an individual’s U.S. citizenship status.
term.notes:
Individuals who have a status in Banner of “Non-resident alien for tax purposes” or “Resident alien for tax purposes” are reported as “Non-citizen”.

Individuals who have a status in Banner of “Unknown” are reported as “U.S. citizen”.

Individuals who hold U.S. citizenship are reported as “U.S. Citizen”, regardless of any other citizenships they may hold.

Individuals who are permanent legal residents of the U.S. are reported as “U.S. Permanent Resident” regardless of any other citizenship they may hold.

term.definition: Contains an individual’s self-reported race/ethnicity status.
term.possible_values:
• Hispanic or Latino

  • Black or African American

  • Asian

  • Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

  • American Indian or Alaska Native

  • White

  • Two or more races selected (unduplicated version only)

  • Non-resident alien

  • Unknown
term.notes:
Information in this data element must be self-reported.  The University does not make determinations of an individual’s race/ethnicity unless that information is provided by the individual.

Individuals with a Citizenship other than U.S. Citizen or Permanent Resident are “Non-resident alien” in this data element, regardless of any other information provided.

Individuals who did not provide race/ethnicity information are “Unknown” in this data element.

There are two versions of this data element: standard (duplicated) and unduplicated.   In the standard data element, individuals may be counted multiple times if they selected more than one race/ethnicity category.

In the unduplicated data element:

  • U.S. citizens or permanent residents who select “Hispanic or Latino” are “Hispanic or Latino”, regardless of any other information provided.
  • Individuals who are not “Non-resident alien” or “Hispanic or Latino” are their self-reported race/ethnicity category, provided that they selected only one category.
  • Individuals who selected two or more race/ethnicity options, are reported as “Two or more races selected”
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to present.
term.name: Race Ethnicity

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether an individual’s race/ethnicity information indicates that they are members of a U.S. minority group.
term.possible_values:
• Minority - Individuals who selected any race/ethnicity category other than “White”.  This includes those individuals who selected “White” in conjunction with one or more other categories.
  • Non-minority - Individuals who exclusively selected “White” as their race/ethnicity.
  • Non-Resident Alien - Individuals who have a Citizenship Status other than “U.S. Citizen” or “Permanent Resident”, regardless of any self-reported race/ethnicity information.
  • Unknown - Individuals who did not provide race/ethnicity information.
term.notes: Non-Resident Alien status has precedence over all other status options.  Individuals who are not U.S. citizens or permanent residents will have a minority status of “Non-Resident Alien” regardless of any self-reported race/ethnicity information.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to present.
term.name: Minority Status

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether an individual’s race/ethnicity information indicates that they are members of an historically underrepresented U.S. minority group.
term.possible_values:
• Historically Underrepresented Minority - Individuals who selected any race/ethnicity category other than “White” or “Asian”.  This includes those individuals who selected “White” and/or “Asian” in conjunction with one or more other categories.
  • Non-minority - Individuals who exclusively selected “White” and/or “Asian” as their race/ethnicity.
  • Non-Resident Alien - Individuals who have a Citizenship Status other than “U.S. Citizen” or “Permanent Resident”, regardless of any self-reported race/ethnicity information.
  • Unknown - Individuals who did not provide race/ethnicity information.
term.notes: Non-Resident Alien status has precedence over all other status options.  Individuals who are not U.S. citizens or permanent residents will have a minority status of “Non-Resident Alien” regardless of any self-reported race/ethnicity information.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to present.

term.definition:
An individual who has been confirmed by an admitting office (or other admitting authority), as recorded by the University Registrar, is considered an active student until he or she:

  • Graduates (if degree-seeking)
  • Completes the academic term (if non degree-seeking)
  • Withdraws or is dismissed by the University
  • Fails to enroll for a spring or fall academic term (unless granted a leave of absence by a Dean)
term.notes:
Students who withdraw or are dismissed during an academic term may be considered active for that academic term, at the discretion of the student’s dean.

During the Fall and Spring academic term, students have up until the sixth day of classes to complete the roll call process and students who fail to enroll are inactivated, unless on leave.  Therefore, the use of current term active student data during the first two weeks of an academic term should be done judiciously.

Students taking courses through the Semester Online program who are not otherwise enrolled at Notre Dame are not considered Active Students because they do not complete ND Roll Call.  In Banner, they are coded with the status code OA (Online Active).
term.data_availability: Data is available by term from Fall 1982 to the present

term.definition: Describes degree-seeking students based upon the end goal of their program(s) of study and non degree-seeking students based upon their affiliation with the University or other institutions or their prior academic experience.
term.possible_values:
For degree-seeking students, student level is based upon their program(s) of study:

  • Undergraduate - Students enrolled in a baccalaureate degree-granting program
  • Graduate - Students enrolled in a graduate degree-granting program
  • Professional - Students enrolled in a professional (Law, MBA) degree-granting program

For non degree-seeking students, student level is based upon their affiliation with the University or other institutions or their prior academic experience.  The possible values are (in order of precedence):

  • Employee Non-Degree - Notre Dame employees and their spouses who are enrolled in courses (undergraduate, graduate or professional) but do not have degree-seeking status
  • Cross-Institutional - Students from other institutions taking courses at Notre Dame through a cooperative agreement
  • Pre-College - Students participating in a Notre Dame Pre-College or TRiO program
  • Undergraduate - Post-secondary students enrolled in courses at Notre Dame who have not yet earned a baccalaureate degree
  • Post-baccalaureate - Students who have earned a baccalaureate degree and are admitted as non-degree students.
term.notes:
For a given term, degree-seeking students may have one or more student levels based upon enrollment in multiple academic programs.  Non-degree seeking students may have only one student level.

Students may not be degree-seeking and non-degree seeking during the same term.

Students participating in the Semester Online program from other institutions who are not Active Students at Notre Dame are assigned the level of Undergraduate Non-Degree Seeking students.

See also Student Level Banding.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: Student Level

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Groups student levels for degree-seeking students based upon the end goal of their program(s) of study and non degree-seeking students based upon their affiliation with the University or other institutions or their prior academic experience.
term.possible_values:
For degree-seeking students, student level is based upon their program(s) of study:

  • Undergraduate - Students enrolled in a baccalaureate degree-granting program
  • Post-baccalaureate (Graduate/Professional) - Students enrolled in a graduate or professional degree-granting program

For non degree-seeking students, student level is based upon their affiliation with the University or other institutions or their prior academic experience.  The possible values are (in order of precedence):

  • Employee Non-Degree - Notre Dame employees and their spouses who are enrolled in courses (undergraduate, graduate or professional) but do not have degree-seeking status
  • Cross-Institutional - Students from other institutions taking courses at Notre Dame through a cooperative agreement
  • Pre-College - Students participating in a Notre Dame Pre-College or TRiO program
  • Undergraduate - Post-secondary students enrolled in courses at Notre Dame who have not yet earned a baccalaureate degree
  • Post-baccalaureate - Students who have earned a baccalaureate degree and are admitted as non-degree students.
term.notes:
For a given term, degree-seeking students may have one or more student levels based upon enrollment in multiple academic programs.  Non-degree seeking students may have only one student level.

Students may not be degree-seeking and non-degree seeking during the same term.

Students participating in the Semester Online program from other institutions who are not Active Students at Notre Dame are assigned the level of Undergraduate Non-Degree Seeking students.

Level value of “Post-baccalaureate (Graduate/Professional)” agreed to to provide clarity of what is included.  Over time, “(Graduate/Professional)” may be considered to be removed.  Maintaining the term “Post-baccalaureate” provides consistency with OSPIR and external reporting.

Any set of valid FOAPALs.  For example:

Each FOAPAL contained within the Compensation FOAPAL for a particular individual may also be referred to as a Compensation Funding Source.

In cases where the FOAPAL(s) charged for an individual  were adjusted after a payroll date, those changes will not be reflected in the Compensation FOAPAL data.  This information shows the FOAPAL(s) that were charged at the time of a particular payroll date.

Retirees who have an additional Job besides the Retiree Job will be included as “Part Time”.

term.definition: Identifies the date that a faculty member begins reducing their teaching load before fully retiring.
term.notes: If a value exists for Phased Retirement Begin Date, the Phased Retirement Status must be “Phased Retirement”.
term.name: Phased Faculty Retirement Begin Date

term.definition: Identifies that a faculty member has declared they have or will begin reducing their teaching load over a period of time before fully retiring.
term.notes: If Phased Retirement Status is “Phased Retirement”, there must also be a value for the Phased Retirement Begin Date.
term.name: Phased Faculty Retirement Status

term.definition: Identifies the current percentage of full salary that a faculty member is receiving as a result of reducing their teaching load in preparation for fully retiring.

term.definition: Identifies the date that a faculty member plans to retire from the faculty.
term.notes: If a value exists for Planned Faculty Retirement Date, the Planned Faculty Retirement Status must also be “Planned Retirement”.
term.name: Planned Faculty Retirement Date

term.definition: Identifies that a faculty member has declared they plan to retire on a specific date.
term.notes: If Planned Faculty Retirement Status is “Planned Retirement”, there must also be a value for the Planned Faculty Retirement Date.
term.name: Planned Faculty Retirement Status

term.definition: Measures Staff Separations, as a percentage of average Staff headcount, that occurred during a specified reporting period.
term.notes:
The Staff Separation Percentage is calculated as:

Staff Separation Percentage = Number of Separations in a given Period / Average Headcount over the Period

where

Average Headcount over the Period = (Headcount beginning of period+Headcount end of period) / 2
term.name: Staff Separation Percentage

term.definition: One of the major academic components of the University, normally headed by a Dean
term.possible_values:
The possible values for College include:

  • College of Arts & Letters
  • College of Engineering
  • College of Science
  • Graduate School
  • Law School
  • Mendoza College of Business
  • School of Architecture
  • First Year of Studies
  • University
term.notes:
This definition includes, for analytics purposes, those entities traditionally referred to as either “colleges” or “schools”.

The University college is used to administratively group activity that does not belong to one of the colleges.  This would include activity associated with pre-college, Saint Mary’s, Semester On-Line and Holy Cross College.

For students, the College field contains the name of the college(s) administering the academic degree(s) that a student was pursuing during a given academic term.

When using the College field, students are mapped to the College containing their academic unit.

All incoming freshmen are assigned to First Year of Studies with the code FY.  Those students who complete their first year but do not fulfill the first year academic requirements remain in the First Year of Studies with the code FR.
term.name: College

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Defines a specific instance of a course subject code/course number combination offered during a specific term.
term.possible_values:
Listed as a combination of Course Subject Code, Course Number and Course Section Number.  For example:

  • HIST 10100 01  (History 10100, Section 1)
  • HIST 10100 02  (History 10100, Section 2)
term.notes:
More than one section may be offered for a given course in a given term.

Course Sections may be solo (no cross-listing), or a parent or child for a cross-listed course.

If a course is cross-listed (represented by more than one course subject code/course number combinations), a single Class may represent more than one course section.  For example:

PHIL 43330 01 and PRL 33100 01 are both 3- hour courses taught by Professor Smith and are cross-listed with PRL 33100 01 as the “Primary” or “Parent” course.  The attributes (credit hours, students) of PHIL 43330 01, as a “child” of PRL 33100 01, would “roll up” to PRL 33100 01, as the “Primary” or “Parent”, representing a Class.
term.name: Course Section

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The Course Subject Code is part of the Course ID and describes the general topic of the course.
term.possible_values:
Examples of Course Subject Code and Literal include:

  • EE - Electrical Engineering
  • ENGL - English
  • HIST - History
  • LAW - Law
  • MATH - Mathematics
  • MUS - Music
  • FYS - First Year of Studies
term.notes:
The Course Subject Code is a 2- to 4- alphanumeric code that represents the Course Subject.

This is not the same data table as “Department”, “Academic Unit” or “Field of Study”, even though the values may appear to be the same.

New Course Subjects may be created at the request of an academic unit.

A full set of examples may be found here: http://registrar.nd.edu/pdf/NewCourseNumbersReport.pdf
term.name: Course Subject Code

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Uniquely identifies a course within an Academic Term.  The course ID is made up of: Course Subject Code and Course Number.
term.possible_values:
Examples of Course IDs include:

  • FTT47601
  • PHIL10101

See also Course Subject Code and Course Number.
term.notes:
A Course ID is unique to a specific Academic Term.  The Course ID’s association with a specific course persists for five years after last being used.

A full set of examples may be found here: http://registrar.nd.edu/pdf/NewCourseNumbersReport.pdf
term.name: Course ID

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The Course Number is a part of the Course ID and identifies the course number level and category.
term.notes:
Beginning with Summer, 2005, the 5-digit course number is all numeric and uses the following numbering conventions:

The first digit in the 5-digit course number describes the course number level:

  • 0XXXX = Pre-College course
  • 1XXXX = Freshmen Level course
  • 2XXXX = Sophomore Level course
  • 3XXXX = Junior Level course
  • 4XXXX = Senior Level course
  • 5XXXX = 5th Year Senior / Advanced Undergraduate course
  • 6XXXX = 1st Year Graduate Level course
  • 7XXXX = 2nd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 8XXXX = 3rd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 9XXXX = Upper Graduate Level course

The second digit in the 5-digit course number typically indicates the category of the course:

  • X0XXX = Regular classroom course
  • X1XXX = Lab / Drill / Studio
  • X2XXX = Tutorial / Discussion Group
  • X3XXX = Seminar
  • X4XXX = ND Study Abroad
  • X5XXX = Internship / Field Work
  • X6XXX = Directed Readings
  • X7XXX = Special Studies
  • X8XXX = Thesis / Research / Dissertation
  • X9XXX = Transfer course articulation
term.data_availability: Since 1970
term.name: Course Number

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Uniquely identifies the course section offered within a specific academic term.
term.possible_values:
A two-digit numeric value between 01 and 99.

Examples include:

  • 01
  • 02
term.notes:
Course Section Numbers appear as a suffix in the Course ID.  

Meeting times are independent of the Course Section Number.

There may only be Course Section Numbers for sections offered within a given academic term.  Future and past academic terms may have more, less or the same occurrences of Course Section Numbers.  For example, in the Fall 2013 term, Course PHIL10101 may be offered in 3 sections (resulting in Course Section Numbers 01, 02, and 03).  Then, in the Spring 2013 term, Course PHIL10101 may only be offered in 2 sections (resulting in Course Section Numbers 01 and 02).

Course Section Numbers do not need to be in sequence. For example there can be a Section 02 and 03 and not an 01.
term.name: Course Section Number

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The Course Number Level is derived from the first digit of the Course Number and indicates the level of specialization and depth of the subject matter presented in the course.

  • 2 = Sophomore Level course

  • 4 = Senior Level course

  • 6 = 1st Year Graduate Level course
  • 7 = 2nd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 8 = 3rd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 9 = Upper Graduate Level course
term.notes:
The first digit in the 5-digit course number describes the course number level:

  • 0XXXX = Pre-College course
  • 1XXXX = Freshmen Level course
  • 2XXXX = Sophomore Level course
  • 3XXXX = Junior Level course
  • 4XXXX = Senior Level course
  • 5XXXX = 5th Year Senior / Advanced Undergraduate course
  • 6XXXX = 1st Year Graduate Level course
  • 7XXXX = 2nd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 8XXXX = 3rd Year Graduate Level course (MBA / LAW)
  • 9XXXX = Upper Graduate Level course

The Course Number Level values generally coincide with the Student Classification values.
term.name: Course Number Level

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

  • 9 = Transfer course articulation
term.notes:
The second digit in the 5-digit course number typically indicates the category of the course:

  • X0XXX = Regular classroom course
  • X1XXX = Lab / Drill / Studio
  • X2XXX = Tutorial / Discussion Group
  • X3XXX = Seminar
  • X4XXX = ND Study Abroad
  • X5XXX = Internship / Field Work

Course Category is loosely defined at the Department’s discretion when creating Course Numbers.
term.name: Course Category

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Groups the Course Categories into groupings of “Classes”, “Research and Independent Study” and “Labs and Tutorials”.
term.possible_values:
The Course Categories are:

The bands are defined as follows:

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Indicates the student’s progress toward his or her academic degree based upon academic credits accumulated and/or number of academic terms completed in an academic program.
term.possible_values:
For undergraduate students, the possible values in this field include:

  • Freshman
  • Sophomore
  • Junior
  • Senior
  • Fifth Year Architecture

The classification of undergraduate students is determined by both the number of semesters of attendance and the number of credits earned.  The University Registrar and the student’s dean (or the dean’s designee) will determine the appropriate classification for each student.

For two-year MBA students, the possible values in this field include:

  • MBA1 - Students who are in the first year of the two-year MBA program
  • MBA2 - Students who are in the second year of the two-year MBA program

For Executive MBA students, the possible values in this field include:

  • EMBA1 - Students who are in the first year of the Executive MBA program
  • EMBA2 - Students who are in the second year of the Executive MBA program

For JD students, the possible values in this field include:

  • Law1 - Students who are in the first year of the JD program
  • Law2 - Students who are in the second year of the JD program
  • Law3 - Students who are in the third year of the JD program

For degree-seeking graduate students enrolled in the Graduate School, this field contains either “Masters” or “PhD”  For other degree seeking post-baccalaureate students in programs that do not designate year in program, the field contains a combination of degree level and program.

For non-degree seeking students, this field contains “Non-Degree Seeking”.
term.notes: The Student Classification Detail field contains additional information on the number of semesters completed at a particular student classification.
term.name: Student Classification

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Indicates the student’s progress within his or her classification based upon academic credits accumulated and/or number of academic terms completed in an academic program.
term.possible_values:
For undergraduate degree-seeking students, the possible values are:

  • Freshman First Semester
  • Freshman Second Semester
  • Sophomore First Semester
  • Sophomore Second Semester
  • Junior First Semester
  • Junior Second Semester
  • Senior First Semester
  • Senior Second Semester
  • Fifth Year Architecture First Semester
  • Fifth Year Architecture Second Semester

Some graduate and professional programs (e.g. MBA, EMBA) track student classification detail by number of semesters completed.  For example, these values include:

  • MBA First Semester
  • MBA Second Semester
  • MBA Third Semester
  • MBA Fourth Semester

Other graduate and professional programs (e.g. JD) track student classification detail by a combination of years and semesters completed.  For example, these values include:

  • First Year Law First Semester
  • First Year Law Second Semester
  • Second Year Law First Semester
  • Second Year Law Second Semester
  • Third Year Law First Semester
  • Third Year Law Second Semester

For students enrolled in programs that do not track Student Classification Detail, the contents of this field are identical to the contents of Student Classification.
term.notes: Rolled up information is available in the Student Classification field, which uses the values “Freshman”, “Sophomore”, “Junior”, “Senior”, and “Fifth Year Architecture” to describe undergraduate students, for example.
term.data_availability: Fall 1982 to the present
term.name: Student Classification Detail

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
The total number of credit hours accumulated by a student at a given point in time.  This is calculated as the sum of:

  • Credit Hours, Earned - academic credit hours earned at Notre Dame, St. Mary’s College or in an official off-site program while an active student at Notre Dame

  • Credit Hours, In Progress - academic credit hours registered for during the current term but not yet earned

  • Credit Hours, AP/IB/CE - academic credit hours granted by the University based upon Advanced Placement testing, International Baccalaureate testing, or Credit by Exam.

  • Credit Hours, Transfer - academic credit hours earned at another institution and accepted by the University
term.notes: Credit hours earned at St. Mary’s College are treated in different ways depending upon the status of the student when the credit hours are earned.  If the student is an active student at Notre Dame at the time those credit hours are earned, those credits are counted as Credit Hours Earned.  If the student is not an active student at Notre Dame at the time those credit hours are earned, the credit hours are treated as Transfer Credit Hours.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: Credit Hours, Total

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Unit of measure giving value to the academic rigor and/or the time requirements for a course.
term.notes:
Per the US Department of Education:

An amount of work represented in intended learning outcomes and verified by evidence of student achievement that is an institutionally established equivalency that reasonably approximates not less than:

  1. One hour of classroom or direct faculty instruction and a minimum of two hours of out-of-class student work each week for approximately fifteen weeks for one semester or trimester hour of credit, or ten to twelve weeks for one quarter hour of credit, or the equivalent amount of work over a different amount of time; or
  2. At least an equivalent amount of work as required in paragraph (1) of this definition for other academic activities as established by the institution including laboratory work, internships, practica, studio work, and other academic work leading to the award of credit hour

At Notre Dame, a credit hour is typically 750 contact minutes during the course of a term.
term.name: Credit Hour

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
An active student who is enrolled for a given academic term is credit-bearing if he or she is:

  • Registered in any course for academic credit; or
  • Registered for a thesis or dissertation course
term.notes:
Students registered for a thesis or dissertation course are counted as credit-bearing students, regardless of whether they are registered in that course for credit.

Students who are exclusively registered in non-thesis/dissertation courses on a zero-credit basis are not counted as credit-bearing students.
term.data_availability: Fall 1982 to Present
term.name: Credit-Bearing Student

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether a student earned Dean’s List recognition during a particular academic term
term.notes:
For undergraduate students, the dean's honor list is restricted to those students who 1) carry at least 12 graded credit hours in the previous semester and 2) have a grade point average in that semester which meets a minimum requirement set by the dean of any college or school in which they are currently enrolled. At the beginning of each academic year, each college and school will choose and make known to its students and the University Registrar the necessary minimum grade point average. This choice will be made so that by best estimates 30 percent of the students in the college or school will receive dean's honor list in a given semester.

In the Law School, eligibility for the dean's list is governed by the Hoynes Code.

This field is Not Applicable for students other than undergraduates or Law students.
term.name: Deans List Status

term.definition:
Externally reportable enrolled students include all active students who are:

  • Enrolled for a given academic term
  • Credit-bearing students for that academic term
  • Not enrolled at a Student Level of Cross-Institutional or Pre-College
term.possible_values:
• Externally Reportable Enrolled Student
  • Non-Externally Reportable Enrolled Student
term.notes:
Students on leave are not included in this count, as they are not enrolled while on leave.

Externally reportable enrolled students include students who have a non-degree-seeking Student Level.

Reporting to external sources is normally done based upon the externally reportable enrolled student count as of the census date chosen for a given academic term.  

Reporting from the data warehouse will include students who meet the criteria in the definition for the academic term at the time the report is run.  That is, reporting from the data warehouse will include late-arriving data that may not be included in OSPIR freeze data.

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether a field of study is a major, minor or concentration for a given student.
term.notes:
The Field of Study Type “Major” includes both “Majors” and “Supplementary Majors”.

The data model contains three measures based upon this field that have the following names for convenience:

  • Majors – filters to those records containing a Field of Study Type of “Major”
  • Minors – filters to those records containing a Field of Study Type of “Minor”

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Groups individuals into categories based upon their GPA
term.notes: These GPA bands may be applied to any GPA-related field, including Cumulative GPA, Term GPA and Level GPA.
term.data_availability: Fall 1982 to present
term.name: GPA, Banding

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
The total number of credit hours attempted by a student that are counted when calculating the student’s GPA.  This includes:

  • Classes taken for a grade at Notre Dame
  • Classes taken for a grade at St. Mary’s College while an active student at Notre Dame
  • Classes taken for a grade in a Notre Dame official off-site program
  • Classes taken on a Pass/Fail basis at Notre Dame where the student fails
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: GPA Credit Hours

term.definition:
Student’s grade point average calculated by dividing the sum of the quality points earned at a specific student level by the number of GPA Credit Hours at that student level and rounded to the third decimal place.

The cumulative GPA calculated as of a given academic term includes all credits attempted up to and including that term.
term.notes:
Students enrolled in multiple student levels receive separate Cumulative GPAs for each of those levels.

This definition is also referred to as Running Cumulative GPA.

Cumulative GPA calculations exclude transfer credit, AP/IB/CE credit and consortium (i.e. St. Mary’s College) credit.

When reporting describes an individual student, the GPA is calculated using the formula described above.  

When reporting describes a population of students, the GPA is calculated as the sum of quality points earned by that population divided by the number of GPA Credit Hours for that population.  The calculated GPAs of each student should not be averaged.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: GPA, Cumulative

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
Student’s grade point average calculated by dividing the sum of the quality points earned at a specific student level by the number of GPA Credit Hours at that student level and rounded to the third decimal place.

The GPA, Level includes all credits attempted at a particular student level, regardless of Academic Term.
term.notes:
Students enrolled in multiple student levels receive separate GPAs for each of those levels.

For students who have completed their work at a particular level, this value is equivalent to the Final GPA for that level.

Level GPA calculations exclude transfer credit, AP/IB/CE credit and consortium (i.e. St. Mary’s College) credit.

When reporting describes an individual student, the GPA is calculated using the formula described above.  

When reporting describes a population of students, the GPA is calculated as the sum of quality points earned by that population divided by the number of GPA Credit Hours for that population.  The calculated GPAs of each student should not be averaged.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: GPA, Level

term.definition: Student’s grade point average for an academic term calculated by dividing the sum of the quality points earned during an academic term by the number of GPA Credit Hours during that term and rounding to the third decimal place.
term.notes:
Students enrolled in multiple student levels during a term receive separate Term GPAs for each of those levels.

Term GPA calculations exclude transfer credit, AP/IB/CE credit and consortium (i.e. St. Mary’s College) credit.

When reporting describes an individual student, the GPA is calculated using the formula described above.  

When reporting describes a population of students, the GPA is calculated as the sum of quality points earned by that population divided by the number of GPA Credit Hours for that population.  The calculated GPAs of each student should not be averaged.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present.
term.name: GPA, Term

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition:
The change in a percent value from one period to another, calculated using the following formula:

Where:

CIP = Vp2-Vp1

SGR: Simple growth rate
Vp1: Value at beginning of period
Vp2: Value at end of period
term.notes: This formula should only be applied to data expressed in the form of a percentage.  It expresses the result in terms of the absolute change in percentage points.  For example, the growth of a percent value from 50% to 60% is a 10% change in percentage, rather than a 20% increase.
term.name: Growth Rate, Change in Percentage

term.definition:
The percent change in a value from one period to another, calculated using the following formula:

Where:

SGR = (Vp2-Vp1) / Vp1

SGR: Simple growth rate
Vp1: Value at beginning of period
Vp2: Value at end of period
term.notes: This formula should not be applied to data expressed in the form of a percentage.  In those cases, the formula in Growth Rate, Change in Percentage should be used.
term.name: Growth Rate, Simple

term.definition: Indicates whether an applicant’s mother, father, step-parent or legal guardian has earned an academic degree from Notre Dame.

  • Non-Legacy - the applicant does not meet the criteria for Legacy status
term.notes: Any academic degree (graduate or undergraduate) earned by a mother, father, step-parent, or legal guardian qualifies an individual for legacy status.
term.data_availability:

Legacy status information is not collected for students other than undergraduates and this field should not be analyzed for other populations.

term.possible_values:

  • For individuals with permanent residence outside the United States, the place of origin is a country name.
term.notes:
• Each active student is assigned a place of origin for each academic term. If an active student has a new confirmed admission for that academic term (e.g. an undergraduate dual enrolls in the MBA program), the place of origin is based upon the student’s home address as of the beginning of that academic term.  Otherwise, the place of origin remains the same as the previous academic term.

term.definition: A student’s enrollment progression based upon admission condition and history of previous enrollments at Notre Dame and other institutions of higher education.
term.possible_values:
• New First Time - Students enrolled at the University for the first time at their present student level who do not qualify as Transfer students.
  • Transfer - Students enrolled at the University for the first time who have previously earned credit at an institution of higher education that is being accepted by the University for their current program.
  • Continuing - Students enrolled at the University who had an enrollment status of Continuing, New First Time, Transfer or Returning during the prior non-summer academic term.
  • Returning - Students enrolled at the University who previously earned academic credit at the University but were neither enrolled nor on a leave of absence during the prior non-summer academic term.  This status is also referred to as “readmit”.
  • Transient - Students enrolled at the University on a temporary basis who have a primary affiliation with another institution of higher education.
  • Special - Students enrolled at the University who do not meet the criteria for any of the other continuation types.
term.notes: Students on leave are considered “Continuing”.
term.data_availability: Data is available from 1982 to the present for the Continuing, Transfer and New First Time continuation types.  Data is available from 2005 to the present for other continuation types.
