term.definition: Contains the enrollment status for an active student during a given academic term.
term.possible_values:
• Enrolled - An active student who has completed the roll call process for an academic term is considered enrolled for that term.  Students may also be manually maintained on enrolled status at the discretion of the University Registrar.
  • Not Enrolled - An active student who does not meet the criteria above.
term.notes:
Enrollment through ND Roll Call is a required process which informs the University that a student is attending a particular semester. This is different from registration.  Registration is adding courses to a student's schedule.

Inactive students do not have an enrollment status.

Students who are on a leave of absence from the University are considered active students but are not considered enrolled.
term.data_availability:
Data is available by term from Fall 1982 to the present.

During the Fall and Spring academic term, students have up until the sixth day of classes to complete the roll call process.  Therefore, the use of enrolled student data for the current term prior to this day should be done judiciously.
term.name: Student Enrollment Status

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the academic term that a student first enrolled at a particular student level at Notre Dame.
term.notes:
Undergraduate students are normally assigned to the cohort term corresponding to the Fall semester of the academic year they began their program.  For example, undergraduate students beginning in Summer Session 2012, Fall Semester 2012 and Spring Semester 2013 would all be assigned to the Fall 2012 cohort.  This does not apply to undergraduate students with a Student Continuation Type of Transfer.  Transfer students are assigned to the actual academic term that they begin.

Graduate and professional students are normally assigned to the cohort term corresponding to the academic term they began their program.  For example, a graduate student beginning in August 2012 would be assigned to the Fall 2012 cohort.  A graduate student beginning in January 2013 would be assigned to the Spring 2013 cohort.  A graduate student beginning in June 2013 would be assigned to the Summer 2013 cohort.

Due to the way data is stored within the ERP, students who are pursuing a professional degree within the Graduate School who enroll in a professional degree program within another college will receive a new Student Entering Cohort Term despite the fact that they have not changed student levels.

Similarly, a student who is pursuing a professional degree outside of the Graduate School who begin a professional degree within the Graduate School will receive a new Student Entering Cohort Term, as will professional students outside of the Graduate School who switch colleges.
term.data_availability: Fall 1982 to the present
term.name: Student Entering Cohort Term

term.notes:
Due to the way data is stored within the ERP, students who are pursuing a professional degree within the Graduate School who enroll in a professional degree program within another college will receive a new Student Entering Cohort Year despite the fact that they have not changed student levels.

Similarly, a student who is pursuing a professional degree outside of the Graduate School who begin a professional degree within the Graduate School will receive a new Student Entering Cohort Year, as will professional students outside of the Graduate School who switch colleges.

  • Part-time - Students enrolled for a term who do not meet the minimum requirements for full-time status.  Part-time students are assigned to one of three subcategories based upon business rules defined for each term by the University Registrar:

term.definition: Describes the degree of academic achievement or mastery of the course elements by a specific student upon completion of a specific course.
term.possible_values:
Grades used in computation of the grade point average:

  • A
  • A-
  • B+
  • B
  • B-
  • C+
  • C
  • C-
  • D
  • F
  • X
  • I

Grades not used in the computation of the grade point average:

  • TR - Transfer Credit
  • AD - Advanced Placement Credit
  • CE - Credit by exam
  • IB - International Baccalaureate
  • S - Satisfactory work
  • U - Unsatisfactory work
  • V - Auditor
  • F* - An individual student’s grade is not reported
  • W - Discontinued with permission
  • P - Pass in a course taken on a pass-fail basis
  • NR - Not Reported
  • Grade Pending
  • No Grade Expected
term.notes:
This is the grade submitted by the instructor at the end of the term.  This grade is then recorded by the Registrar (and may be changed by appropriate academic procedure after submission by the instructor) and becomes the grade that appears on the student’s transcript.

In Banner, the “No Grade Expected” and “Grade Pending” will appear as blanks.

Further definition for grades:

  • X - Given with the approval by the dean in extenuating circumstances beyond the control of the student. Reverts to “F” if not changed within 30 days after the beginning of the next semester
  • S - Satisfactory work (courses with zero semester credit hours, as well as research courses, departmental seminars or colloquia or directed studies; workshops; field education and skill courses)
  • U - Unsatisfactory work (courses with zero semester credit hours, as well as research courses, departmental seminars or colloquia or directed studies; workshops; field education and skill courses).
  • V - Auditor (graduate students only)
  • F* - Temporary when an individual student’s grade is not reported)
  • W - Discontinued with permission.
  • P - Pass in a course taken on a pass-fail basis.
  • NR - Final grade(s) for the entire Class are not reported by the instructor due to extenuating circumstances.
  • Grade Pending - Used when Registrar’s Office is expecting a grade to be reported but none has been reported
  • No Grade Expected - Used for for student(s) who dropped the class or a when a student has take a class for no grade
term.name: Final Grade

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The average of the grade quality points for all students enrolled in a specific course unweighted by credit hours.
term.notes:
To calculate the Course Average Grade:

For all students registered for and receiving a grade that awards grade quality points for all sections of a given Course:
(sum of grade quality points) / (the number of students receiving grades that have grade quality points)

Grade quality points are defined as:

  • A = 4.000 quality points)
  • A- = 3.667 quality points
  • B+ = 3.333 quality points
  • B = 3.000 quality points
  • B- = 2.667 quality points
  • C+ = 2.333 quality points
  • C = 2.000 quality points
  • C- = 1.667 quality points
  • D = 1.000 quality points
  • X = 0.000 quality points
  • I = 0.000 quality points
  • F = 0.000 quality points

Students with grades that are not used in the calculation of a student’s GPA (e.g., S, U, V, W, P, F* and NR) are not used in calculating the Course Average Grade.

For example:

HIST30123 has two sections in which there are 4 students registered for one section and 2 for the second section (total of 6 students registered for HIST20123).  The 6 students receive the following grades, respectively: A-, B, B, C, P and F.  The Course Average Grade would be calculated as:

(3.667+3+3+2+0)/5 or 2.33, corresponding to a C+.

Note that the student’s “P” grade does not factor into the calculation as the “P” does not count toward calculating a GPA.
term.name: Course Average Grade

term.definition: Associates a particular course with the college that offers the course.

  • Four-digit number in the summer term.
term.name: Course Reference Number

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Associates a specific Course Section with the Academic Term in which it is offered.
term.name: Course Section Academic Term

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies anyone affiliated with the instruction or administration of a course section.
term.possible_values:
Individual names.  For example:

  • R. Scott Appleby
  • Ann Tenbrunsel
term.notes:
There may be more than one Course Section Affiliate for a course section.

A Course Section Affiliate may be:

  • A person actually doing instruction (e.g. a faculty member teaching the class)
  • A Teaching Assistant assisting with the class, leading discussion groups, monitoring laboratory work … etc.)
  • An individual who is grading papers and exams, but not actually participating in the instructional component of the class
  • An administrative assistant who enters grades or otherwise  supports the execution of the class without actually participating in instructional activities.
term.name: Course Section Affiliate

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies if a Course Section Affiliate is participating in the instruction or is performing administrative support.
term.possible_values:
• Instructional – Participating as an instructor
  • Administrative – Participating in the administration of the course section.
term.notes:
Instructional Affiliates for a course section must hold a faculty appointment (or, as an accepted exception, be a graduate student) and are typically assigned an instructor percent responsibility of 2% or more.

Administrative Affiliates for a course section will typically not hold a faculty appointment and performs administrative functions associated with the course section such as entering grades, facilitating instructor-student meetings, scheduling or facilitating out-of-classroom events.
term.name: Course Section Affiliate Type

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the Course Section Affiliates’ respective roles and the level to which the Course Section Affiliates are credited with productivity measures associated with the Course Section.
term.notes:
Instructional Affiliates will have a percent responsibility of 2% or greater.

Administrative Affiliates will have a percent responsibility of 1% or less.
term.name: Course Section Affiliate Percent Responsibility

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the city where a specific course section is being offered.
term.notes: The Course Section City is derived from the values found in http://registrar.nd.edu/campuscodes.pdf
term.name: Course Section City

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The total number of minutes that an instructor and enrolled students meet collectively for a course section during an academic term.
term.notes: Calculated based upon the minutes defined by the start and end times multiplied by the number of days the course section meets.
term.name: Course Section Contact Minutes

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the time of day that a specific Course Section will start during a given academic term.
term.possible_values:
Any time in 12-hour format.  For example:

  • 8:20 AM
  • 3:30 PM
term.notes: A course section can have more than one meeting pattern and associated start and stop times.
term.name: Course Section Start Time

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the time of day that a specific Course Section will end during a given academic term.
term.possible_values:
Any time in 12-hour format.  For example:

  • 9:10 AM
  • 4:20 PM
term.notes: A course section can have more than one meeting pattern and associated start and stop times.
term.name: Course Section End Time

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the country in which a specific course section is being offered.
term.notes: The Course Section Country is a “roll up” of the values found in http://registrar.nd.edu/campuscodes.pdf to the corresponding region found in a table in OSPIR that creates a hierarchy of the Campus Codes into regions and countries.
term.name: Course Section Country

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

target_uri: terms/Course Section Course Instructor Feedback Indicator

term.definition: Identifies which instructors for a given Class will be included in the Course Instructor Feedback process.
term.notes:
For an instructor to be evaluated, the following criteria must be met:

  • He or she must be assigned at least 1% of the course teaching load in a specific course
  • The department chair/designee must indicate in the Course Instructor Feedback Pre-Administration system that the instructor should be evaluated for that specific course
  • The course itself must meet the following criteria:
    • Course must be on campus or at an off-campus location authorized by the Provost’s office to be evaluated in the CIF system
    • Course must have at least 3 total students registered (across all cross-listed sections, including registered auditors) at the time of the evaluation
    • Course must be marked for evaluation in the Course Instructor Feedback Pre-Administration system by the department chair/designee
term.name: Course Section Course Instructor Feedback Indicator

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the number of credit hours or a range of credit hours for which a course section is offered.
term.possible_values: May be represented as a single value or a range of values and may vary for students taking the course section
term.notes: A Course Section may be offered with a range of Credit Hours, depending upon the student’s enrollment in the Course Section.  For example, Student A and Student B are both enrolled in the same Course Section, however, Student A may enroll for 3 credit hours and Student B may enroll for 1 credit hour.
term.name: Course Section Credit Hours

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies if a Course Section is cross-listed and with which course sections the course section is cross-listed.
term.notes:
The code is randomly generated and assigned to all course sections within the cross-listed group.

The Group Codes apply only to the current term.

Course Sections that have no cross listings (Solo course sections) will not have a value for the Cross-List Group Code.
term.name: Course Section Cross-List Group Code

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Designates if and how a Course Section is cross-listed with other course sections.
term.notes:
The Parent Course Section is always the primary course section within the cross-listed group of course sections.

The “Parent” (or “Primary”) Course Section represents the information elements reported in cases where “Child” Course Sections are rolled up.  For example, HIST30101-01 is the parent for AMST20301-01 and POLS30101-01.  Reports that roll up information will display the Title, Subject, Course and Section Numbers for HIST30101-01.

“Solo” Course Sections are not cross-listed and are always considered the primary course section.
term.name: Course Section Cross-List Type

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the final calendar date on which a specific Course Section will meet (excluding the final exam) during a given academic term.
term.notes: The Course Section End Date will not include Final Exam dates.
term.name: Course Section End Date

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The total number of students registered for but who will not be awarded credit hours for the successful completion of a specific course section.
term.notes:
As an example, a student auditing a particular course section will be counted in the Course Section Enrollment Not For-Credit.

The sum of the Course Section Enrollment For-Credit and Course Section Enrollment Not For-Credit will equal the Course Section Enrollment for a given Course Section.
term.name: Course Section Enrollment Not For-Credit

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Describes the percentage of enrollment in a particular Course by students pursuing a degree in a particular College.
term.notes:
This term provides a means for a College to measure the extent to which a course offered by the College is servicing students from other Colleges.

First Year students are counted based upon their Intended College.

Dual degree students will count toward the enrollment percentage for both of their degree colleges, appearing once for each college of their dual degree and an additional time in the denominator.  For example, in a course where the total enrollment is 10 students, and two students are dual degree students as follows:

  • 5 Engineering student
  • 1 A&L student
  • 1 Business student
  • 1 Science student
  • 2 students are Engineering and Science Dual Degree

The Class Enrollment Percentage College is calculated as follows:

  • Engineering (5+2)/(10+2) = 58.3%
  • A&L 1/(10+2) = 8.3%
  • Business 1/(10+2) = 8.3%
  • Science (1+2)/(10+2) = 25.0%

where the "+2" in all cases accounts for the dual degree students counted in each of their degree colleges.
term.name: Course Enrollment Percentage College

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Course Section Grade Mode describes the type of grades that can be awarded for the Course Section.
term.notes:
A course can have multiple Course Section Grade Modes.

Transfer and No Grade Given are associated with Gradable Course Status of “Not Gradable”.

If different, Course Section Grade Modes supercede Course Grade Modes, allowing sections of a course to offer different Grade Modes.
term.name: Course Section Grade Mode

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Defines the beginning and end dates, meeting pattern and the start and stop times for when a specific course section meets.
term.notes:
A course section can have multiple Course Section Meeting Times.

The Course Section Meeting Time combines the individual elements of Course Section Start Time, End Time, Start Date, End Date and Meeting Pattern.
term.name: Course Section Meeting Time

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the first calendar date on which a specific Course Section will meet during a given academic term.
term.name: Course Section Start Date

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Defines the default start date, end date and registration add and drop deadlines, as well as to manage the grade submission process at the end of the part of term for a Course Section.
term.possible_values:
Examples of values are:

  • Q1 (First Quarter Fall Semester)
  • Q2 (Second Quarter Fall Semester)
  • Q3 (Third Quarter Spring Semester)
  • Q4 (Fourth Quarter Spring Semester)
  • SS1 (Summer Session)
  • SS2 (Summer Session)
  • Part of Term 1 (Full Term Excluding First Monday)
  • Part of Term X (Full Term Including First Monday)
term.notes:
See also “Academic Term”.

Used to enforce and to manage the grade submission process at the end of the part of term.
term.name: Course Section Part of Term

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies one of the Course Section Affiliates who is designated the most responsible for the course section instruction.
term.notes:
In course section listings, the Course Section Affiliate designated as the Primary Instructor will appear first when all affiliates are listed.  If only one affiliate is listed, the Primary Instructor will be the affiliate listed.

The Primary Instructor must hold a faculty appointment or, as an accepted exception, may be a graduate student.

While the academy may consider all instructors to be participating and sharing equally in the course section delivery, the “Primary Instructor” designation is intended to identify one of the Course Section Affiliates as most responsible for the course section.

There may only be one Primary Instructor.

Off campus courses are often assigned with instructors who are course managers or other administrative roles (e.g. international courses), so the Primary Instructor may be an Administrative Affiliate.
term.name: Course Section Primary Instructor

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the physical location and program where a specific course section is being offered.
term.possible_values:
Two character Campus Code from http://registrar.nd.edu/campuscodes.pdf

For example:

  • LG (London, England, Engineering)
  • LM (London, England, Law-LLM)
  • LS (London, England, Summer)
  • SC (Santiago, Chile)
  • SG (Shanghai, China, MBA)
  • SH (Shanghai, China)
  • SM (Saint Mary’s College)
term.notes: See also the terms “Campus”, “Course Section City”, “Course Section Country” and “Course Section Region”
term.name: Course Section Program Location

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the global region in which a specific course section is being offered.
term.notes: The Course Section Region is a “roll up” of the values found in http://registrar.nd.edu/campuscodes.pdf to the corresponding region found in a table in OSPIR that creates a hierarchy of the Campus Codes into regions and countries.
term.name: Course Section Region

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The association of a given student enrolled with a specific course section within a given term.
term.name: Course Section Registration

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: The number of credit hours for which a given student has registered for a given course section.
term.notes: The sum of the Course Section Registration Credit Hours for each student registered for a given course section becomes the Course Section Credit Hours Generated.
term.name: Course Section Registration Credit Hours

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Measures the effort expended for a given course section as the sum of the credit hours for which each student is enrolled for all students enrolled in a course section.
term.notes:
The Credit Hours Generated is a measure of effort for a given course section, regardless of the passing or failing of the students enrolled for credit.  While dependent upon the time the measurement is taken (beginning of term and end of term may be different if students drop or add the course section during the academic term), this is typically measured at the beginning of the term (frozen at one month into the term).

For example: 3 students are enrolled in a course section. Student A is enrolled for 3 credit hours, Student B for 2 credit hours and student C is taking the course for 1 credit hour.  Students A and C receive passing grades, Student B does not.  The Credit Hours Generated for this course section are 3+2+1=6.
term.name: Credit Hours Generated

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Associates the name of the building in which the specific course section session is being offered or held.
term.notes: Depending upon the outcome o governance discussions for Space terms, it will then be decided if it is more appropriate to use the “Official” building name or the “Common” building name.
term.name: Course Section Session Building

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether a student is receiving an athletic grant-in-aid (GIA) during a given academic term.
term.notes:
A student will have the “GIA Athlete” association if the student is receiving Grant in Aid scholarship (GATH) or Books (Books) aid.

A student athlete with GIA Athlete status must remain on an NCAA Team roster.  

For a student athlete who separates from the university, the end of term status would be “Non Athlete” but the GIA Athlete status would remain at the end of term.
term.name: GIA Athlete Status

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: If a course is Not Variable Credit, this identifies the fixed number of credit hours that may be attempted by a student enrolled in the course section.
term.name: Non-Variable Credit Hours

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: If a course is Variable Credit, this describes the range of possible credit hours that may be attempted by a student enrolled in the course section.
term.name: Variable Credit Hours

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies that a course section may result in different credits attempted/awarded for different students enrolled in the course section.
term.name: Variable Credit Status

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies an Active Student that is registered for at least one Course Section during a given academic term.
term.notes: See also “Active Student”
term.name: Registered Student

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Indicates that a Course Section will require a reservation in a Registrar-controlled classroom.
term.notes: Typically, course sections that do not require a classroom are course sections that have variable meeting times and locations or meet in space controlled by the department.
term.name: Registrar Classroom Needed Indicator

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the Grade Mode to be used for a student based upon how that student is registered for the course section.
term.notes:
A student may only have one Registration Grade Mode for each course section for which the student is registered.

See also "Course Section Grade Mode".
term.name: Registration Course Grade Mode

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether or not a course can be taken by a student, without special permission, even when the student already has credit for previously completing the course.
term.notes:
The dean's office of each college reserves the authority to determine what credits count toward degree-credit for
graduation purposes.

This is typically used for courses such as independent study or directed readings.
term.name: Repeatable Course Status

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies whether or not a student meets all of the following criteria for satisfactory academic progress: (a) maintains minimum cumulative grade point average and (b) remains on pace to graduate and (c) will complete their degree within the maximum allowed timeframe.
term.notes:
The US Department of Education specifies the definition of remaining “on pace” for graduation.

The status of a student’s academic progress is reviewed once each academic year during the Spring term unless the student is in a one year or less program or on a financial aid plan, each of which requires the student’s status to be reviewed every term.

This status applies to all students, regardless of their financial aid status.
term.name: Satisfactory Academic Progress

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the varsity sport (or sports) for which the student appears on the squad list.
term.possible_values:
Examples of possible Sport values are:

  • Football
  • Baseball
  • Men’s Basketball
  • Women’s Basketball
  • Cross Country
  • Fencing
  • Men’s Golf
  • Women’s Golf
  • Hockey
  • Men’s Lacrosse
  • Women’s Lacrosse
  • Men’s Soccer
  • Women’s Soccer
  • Softball
  • Men’s Swimming & Diving
  • Women’s Swimming & Diving
  • Men’s Tennis
  • Women’s Tennis
  • Track & Field
  • Rowing
  • Volleyball
  • Not On Roster
term.notes:
Cheerleaders, student workers, student managers and student trainers do not appear on squad lists.

Male practice players who appear on the squad list of a women’s sport do not appear on squad lists.
term.name: Sport

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the College offering the Academic Degree that the student is pursuing.
term.notes:
A list of currently offered degrees may be found at http://registrar.nd.edu/pdf/Curricula.pdf

Dual degree students will be associated with both degree colleges.
term.name: Student Degree College

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies the actual contact minutes for a course section or a class as a percentage of the standard number of contact minutes specified by the maximum possible credit hours for the course section or class.
term.notes:
This applies only to Undergraduate Level courses.

The following is an example of how this may be calculated:

  • 3 Credit Hour course at 750 contact minutes per credit hour for 2,250 contact minutes
  • Meets for 50 minutes, 3x per week (41 times) for 2,050 minutes during the term.
  • The Undergraduate Contact Minutes Percentage would be 91% (2,050/2,250)

This measure does not include the final exam.
term.name: Undergraduate Contact Minutes Percentage

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies which, if any, university undergraduate core requirements a course section fulfills as approved by the appropriate core curriculum subcommittee.
term.possible_values:
• University Requirement Fine Arts (FNAR)
  • University Requirement History (HIST)
  • University Requirement Literature (LIT)
  • University Requirement Mathematics (MATH)
  • University Requirement Natural Science (NASC)
  • University Requirement Physical Education (PE)
  • University Requirement 2nd Philosophy (PHI2)
  • University Requirement 1st Philosophy (PHIL)
  • University Requirement Social Science (SOSC)
  • University Requirement Developmental Theology (THE2)
  • University Requirement 1st Theology (THEO)
  • University Requirement University Seminar (USEM)
  • University Requirement Writing & Rhetoric (WRRH)
  • Not a University Requirement (implied by the absence of any of the approvals listed above)
term.notes: A course section might not be approved to meet any University core requirement, and a course section may be approved to meet more than one University core requirement.
term.name: University Core Requirement

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies if a course section, as approved by the appropriate core curriculum subcommittee, fulfills any university undergraduate core requirements.
term.name: University Core Requirement Indicator

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies a Class that has a Class Enrollment of zero (0).
term.name: Zero Enrollment Class

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: Identifies a Course Section that has a Course Section Enrollment of zero (0).
term.name: Zero Enrollment Course Section

stakeholders.name: Office of Strategic Planning and Institutional Research

term.definition: An alphanumeric sequence that uniquely identifies a specific Federal Job Code for the purpose of United States Federal Affirmative Action reporting.
term.possible_values:
The Federal Job Group Code is a character alphanumeric.  Examples include:

Federal Job Group Code Federal Job Group
ADM Administrator
MS Supervisor
term.notes:
Federal Job Groups are the basic units for developing availability proportions, conducting the utilization analysis, and
analyzing personnel transactions in accordance with Federal affirmative action regulations.
term.name: Federal Job Group Code

term.definition: A four digit number that represents an occupation classification from the most recent US Census.
term.possible_values:
The Federal Job Census Code is a four-digit code.  Examples include:

Federal Job Census Code Census Occupation
0010 Chief Executives
0230 Education Administrators
2200 Post-Secondary Teachers
5700 Secretaries and Administrative Assistants
term.name: Federal Job Census Code
